title: Vegetarian Pad See Ew
description: A hearty, wok-tossed Thai stir-fry of wide rice noodles with crisp-tender Chinese broccoli, tofu and a savory-sweet soy sauce. Smoky char from high-heat searing balances sweet and salty flavors for a comforting, fast weeknight meal.

ingredients.display_name: dried wide rice noodles (sen yai) or fresh wide rice noodles
ingredients.notes: if dried, soak according to package until pliable but slightly firm; if fresh, separate gently

ingredients.display_name: firm tofu, pressed and cut into 1/2-inch cubes
ingredients.notes: press 15–30 minutes to remove excess water

ingredients.display_name: chinese broccoli (gai lan), trimmed and cut into 2-3 inch pieces
ingredients.notes: use stems and leaves; if unavailable, use broccoli florets and stems
optional for vegan substitution (omit) — recipe not vegan as written

ingredients.display_name: garlic, peeled and thinly sliced or minced
light soy sauce (regular salty soy sauce)
dark soy sauce (for color and mild sweetness)

ingredients.notes: if unavailable, increase light soy and add 1 tsp mushroom bouillon powder

ingredients.display_name: lightly crushed white pepper or ground white pepper
red chili flakes or sliced fresh thai bird chiles
coarse salt (for blanching stems if needed)

steps.text: Prep and soak noodles: If using dried wide rice noodles, place them in warm water and soak until pliable but still slightly firm to the bite; drain and set aside. If using fresh, separate gently. Meanwhile press and cube tofu, trim and cut Chinese broccoli, mince garlic and slice scallions.
Make sauce: In a small bowl combine light soy sauce, dark soy sauce, vegetarian oyster sauce, sugar and toasted sesame oil; stir until sugar dissolves and set near the stove.

Pan-fry tofu: Heat a wok or large skillet over medium-high heat and add 1 tablespoon vegetable oil. Add tofu cubes in a single layer and fry, turning occasionally, until golden on at least two sides and crisp, about 4–5 minutes; remove and set aside.

Blanch Chinese broccoli (optional for faster stir): Bring a small pot of salted water to a boil and blanch the thick stems 30–45 seconds until bright green and slightly tender; drain and refresh in cold water, then drain again. Alternatively, stir-fry directly in the wok in the next step.

Stir-fry aromatics and eggs: Return the wok to high heat, add remaining oil and swirl. Add garlic and stir 15–20 seconds until fragrant without burning. Push garlic to the side, pour in beaten eggs and scramble quickly until just set, breaking into pieces.

Combine noodles and sauce: Add drained noodles to the wok, toss to combine with eggs and garlic, then pour the prepared sauce over the noodles. Stir-fry on high heat, using tongs or spatula to toss and toss frequently so sauce coats noodles evenly and they begin to char slightly, about 2–3 minutes.

Add vegetables and tofu: Add blanched or raw Chinese broccoli and the fried tofu to the wok. Continue stir-frying on high heat, pressing noodles lightly against the hot surface to get smoky char spots, tossing until broccoli is tender-crisp and everything is hot, about 3–4 minutes. Taste and adjust seasoning if needed.

Finish and serve: Turn off heat, sprinkle sliced scallions and optional white pepper, drizzle a little extra toasted sesame oil if desired. Serve immediately with lime wedges and optional chili flakes on the side.
